locations.name: Normandy D-Day Beaches
locations.description: Historic landing sites of the Allied invasion of Nazi-occupied France on June 6, 1944
locations.significance: Operation Overlord, the largest seaborne invasion in history
locations.details: The Normandy landings were the landing operations and associated airborne operations on Tuesday, 6 June 1944 of the Allied invasion of Normandy in Operation Overlord during World War II. Codenamed Operation Neptune and often referred to as D-Day, it was the largest seaborne invasion in history. The operation began the liberation of France (and later western Europe) and laid the foundations of the Allied victory on the Western Front. Planning for the operation began in 1943. In the months leading up to the invasion, the Allies conducted a substantial military deception, codenamed Operation Bodyguard, to mislead the Germans as to the date and location of the main Allied landings. The beaches are divided into five sectors: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno, and Sword.

locations.name: Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial
locations.description: Former German Nazi concentration and extermination camp, now a memorial to the victims of the Holocaust
locations.significance: The largest of the Nazi concentration camps and extermination centers
locations.details: Auschwitz-Birkenau was a complex of over 40 concentration and extermination camps operated by Nazi Germany in occupied Poland during World War II and the Holocaust. It consisted of Auschwitz I (the main camp), Auschwitz II–Birkenau (a combination concentration/extermination camp), Auschwitz III–Monowitz (a labor camp to staff an IG Farben factory), and 45 satellite camps. Auschwitz I was first constructed to hold Polish political prisoners, who began to arrive in May 1940. The first extermination of prisoners took place in September 1941. Auschwitz II–Birkenau went on to become a major site of the Nazi 'Final Solution to the Jewish question'. From early 1942 until late 1944, transport trains delivered Jews to the camp's gas chambers from all over German-occupied Europe. More than 1.1 million people, around 90 percent of them Jewish, died at Auschwitz. The memorial and museum now stand as a solemn reminder of the atrocities committed during the Holocaust.

locations.name: Pearl Harbor National Memorial
locations.description: Site of the Japanese attack that led to US entry into World War II on December 7, 1941
locations.significance: The attack that brought the United States into World War II
locations.details: Pearl Harbor is a U.S. naval base near Honolulu, Hawaii, that was the scene of a devastating surprise attack by Japanese forces on December 7, 1941. Just before 8 a.m. on that Sunday morning, hundreds of Japanese fighter planes descended on the base, where they managed to destroy or damage nearly 20 American naval vessels, including eight battleships, and over 300 airplanes. More than 2,400 Americans died in the attack, including civilians, and another 1,000 people were wounded. The day after the assault, President Franklin D. Roosevelt asked Congress to declare war on Japan, which they approved. The Pearl Harbor Memorial features several sites, including the USS Arizona Memorial, which marks the resting place of 1,102 sailors and Marines killed on the USS Arizona during the attack. The memorial, built in 1962, straddles the sunken hull of the battleship without touching it.

locations.name: Churchill War Rooms
locations.description: Underground command center where Prime Minister Winston Churchill and his war cabinet directed the war effort
locations.significance: The secret underground headquarters for the British government during WWII
locations.details: The Churchill War Rooms is a museum in London and one of the five branches of the Imperial War Museum. The museum comprises the Cabinet War Rooms, a historic underground complex that housed a British government command center throughout the Second World War, and the Churchill Museum, a biographical museum exploring the life of British statesman Winston Churchill. Construction of the Cabinet War Rooms, located beneath the Treasury building in the Whitehall area of Westminster, began in 1938. They became operational in August 1939, shortly before the outbreak of war in Europe. They remained in operation throughout the Second World War, before being abandoned in August 1945 after the surrender of Japan. The rooms were preserved and opened to the public in 1984, and the museum was reopened in 2005 following a redevelopment. The museum houses many artifacts and interactive displays that tell the story of Churchill's life and legacy.

locations.name: Anne Frank House
locations.description: Biographical museum dedicated to Jewish wartime diarist Anne Frank who hid from Nazi persecution
locations.significance: The hiding place of Anne Frank and her family during Nazi occupation
locations.details: The Anne Frank House is a writer's house and biographical museum dedicated to Jewish wartime diarist Anne Frank. The building is located on a canal called the Prinsengracht, close to the Westerkerk, in central Amsterdam in the Netherlands. During World War II, Anne Frank hid from Nazi persecution with her family and four other people in hidden rooms at the rear of the building. They were betrayed and captured by the Nazis in August 1944. Anne Frank did not survive the Holocaust but her wartime diary was published in 1947. The diary documents her experiences hiding during the German occupation of the Netherlands in World War II. The museum opened on May 3, 1960, and preserves the hiding place, has a permanent exhibition on the life and times of Anne Frank, and has an exhibition space about all forms of persecution and discrimination. The original diary is on display as part of the permanent exhibition.

locations.name: Hiroshima Peace Memorial
locations.description: Memorial park commemorating the atomic bombing of Hiroshima at the end of World War II
locations.significance: Site of the first atomic bombing in history
locations.details: The Hiroshima Peace Memorial, also known as the Genbaku Dome, Atomic Bomb Dome or A-Bomb Dome, is part of the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park in Hiroshima, Japan, and was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1996. The ruin of the hall serves as a memorial to the people who were killed in the atomic bombing of Hiroshima on August 6, 1945. Over 70,000 people were killed instantly, and another 70,000 suffered fatal injuries from the radiation. The building was the only structure left standing near the bomb's hypocenter. The Peace Memorial Park, which surrounds the museum and cenotaph, was built on an open field that was created by the explosion. Today, the memorial park is visited by more than one million people each year, and the museum displays artifacts and stories from the bombing, focusing on the devastating human cost of nuclear weapons and advocating for world peace.

locations.name: Berlin Reichstag Building
locations.description: Historic parliament building that was damaged in WWII and later restored, symbolizing German reunification
locations.significance: The symbolic capture of Berlin by Soviet forces in 1945
locations.details: The Reichstag building is a historic edifice in Berlin, Germany, constructed to house the Imperial Diet of the German Empire. It was opened in 1894 and housed the Diet until 1933, when it was severely damaged after being set on fire. The building fell into disuse during the Nazi era and World War II. The ruined building was partially refurbished in the 1960s, but a full restoration was only completed after German reunification in 1990. After its completion in 1999, it once again became the meeting place of the German parliament: the modern Bundestag. The Reichstag dome, designed by architect Norman Foster, is a glass dome constructed on top of the rebuilt Reichstag building. It features a mirrored cone in the center that directs sunlight into the building and allows visitors to view the parliamentary proceedings from the dome. The dome symbolizes the reunification of Germany and the transparency of the democratic process.

locations.name: Warsaw Uprising Museum
locations.description: Museum dedicated to the Warsaw Uprising of 1944 against the German occupation of Poland
locations.significance: The largest single military effort by any European resistance movement during WWII
locations.details: The Warsaw Uprising Museum is a museum in Warsaw, Poland, dedicated to the Warsaw Uprising of 1944. The institution was established in 1983, but it opened to the public on July 31, 2004, marking the 60th anniversary of the uprising. The museum sponsors research into the history of the uprising, and the history and possessions of the Polish Underground State. It collects and maintains hundreds of artifacts, ranging from weapons used by the insurgents to love letters, in order to present a full picture of the people involved. The museum's exhibits cover the political situation in pre-war Poland, the German invasion, the occupation, the resistance movement, and the uprising itself. The museum also houses a recreation of the sewer systems used by the resistance to move around the city, a replica of a B-24 Liberator bomber, and a memorial wall with the names of those who died during the uprising.

locations.name: Dunkirk Beach
locations.description: Site of the massive evacuation of Allied soldiers during the Battle of France in 1940
locations.significance: The miraculous evacuation of 338,000 Allied troops
locations.details: Dunkirk Beach was the site of Operation Dynamo, the evacuation of Allied soldiers during World War II from the beaches and harbor of Dunkirk, in the north of France, between May 26 and June 4, 1940. The operation became necessary when large numbers of British, French, and Belgian troops were cut off and surrounded by German troops during the Battle of France. The evacuation was ordered on May 26, and a hastily assembled fleet of over 800 boats, including military vessels and civilian craft such as fishing boats and pleasure cruisers (later known as the 'Little Ships of Dunkirk'), sailed across the English Channel to rescue the stranded soldiers. Despite the German air superiority, the Royal Air Force conducted operations to protect the evacuation. In the end, 338,226 soldiers were rescued by a hastily assembled fleet of over 800 vessels. The event is seen as a pivotal moment in World War II and has been immortalized in films, books, and memorials.

locations.name: Bletchley Park
locations.description: Former top-secret codebreaking center where Alan Turing and others deciphered Nazi communications
locations.significance: The site where the Enigma code was broken, shortening WWII by an estimated 2-4 years
locations.details: Bletchley Park is an English country house and estate that became the principal center of Allied code-breaking during World War II. It housed the Government Code and Cypher School (GC&CS), which regularly penetrated the secret communications of the Axis Powers – most importantly the German Enigma and Lorenz ciphers. The mansion was constructed during the 1870s for the English financier and politician Sir Herbert Samuel Leon. During World War II, the estate housed the British government's Code and Cypher School, which worked on breaking the German Enigma and other codes. The team at Bletchley Park, including Alan Turing, developed the Bombe, an electromechanical device used to help break Enigma-enciphered messages. The intelligence produced at Bletchley Park, codenamed Ultra, provided crucial assistance to the Allied war effort and is credited with shortening the war by two to four years. The site is now a museum and heritage attraction, open to the public, featuring exhibitions about the codebreaking operations and the people who worked there.

locations.name: Iwo Jima
locations.description: Site of the famous battle and flag raising that became an iconic image of the Pacific War
locations.significance: The battle that produced the iconic flag-raising photograph
locations.details: Iwo Jima is a small Japanese island in the northwest Pacific Ocean, about 750 miles south of Tokyo. It was the site of the Battle of Iwo Jima between the United States and Imperial Japan during World War II. The American invasion, designated Operation Detachment, had the goal of capturing the entire island, including the three Japanese-controlled airfields, to provide a staging area for attacks on the Japanese main islands. This five-week battle comprised some of the fiercest and bloodiest fighting of the Pacific War. The battle was immortalized by Joe Rosenthal's photograph of the raising of the U.S. flag on top of the 169 m (554 ft) Mount Suribachi by six U.S. Marines, which became an iconic image of the war. Of the 21,000 Japanese soldiers on Iwo Jima at the beginning of the battle, only 216 were taken prisoner, with the rest being killed or missing. After the war, the island was administered by the United States until 1968, when it was returned to Japan.

locations.name: Bastogne War Museum
locations.description: Museum dedicated to the Battle of the Bulge, Hitler's last major offensive on the Western Front
locations.significance: The site of the pivotal Battle of the Bulge
locations.details: The Bastogne War Museum is a World War II museum located in Bastogne, Belgium, near the famous Mardasson Memorial. It focuses on the Battle of the Bulge, which was fought around the town of Bastogne in December 1944 and January 1945. The Battle of the Bulge was the last major German offensive campaign on the Western Front during World War II. It was launched through the densely forested Ardennes region of Wallonia in eastern Belgium, northeast France, and Luxembourg. The surprise attack caught the Allied forces completely off guard. American forces bore the brunt of the attack and incurred their highest casualties of any operation during the war. The battle also severely depleted Germany's armored forces, and they were largely unable to replace them. German personnel and, later, Luftwaffe aircraft (during the Unternehmen Bodenplatte) also sustained heavy losses. The museum uses modern scenography techniques and features numerous artifacts, testimonials, and multi-sensory exhibits to immerse visitors in the history of the battle and the broader context of World War II.
